coredata.dc:title: Highly reversible and safe lithium metal batteries enabled by Non-flammable All-fluorinated carbonate electrolyte conjugated with 3D flexible MXene-based lithium anode
coredata.dc:creator: Qian, Yi
Zhang, Kai
Tan, LiWen
An, YongLing
Xi, Baojuan
Xiong, Shenglin
Feng, Jinkui
Qian, Yitai
coredata.dc:description: Recognized as the most attractive and promising anode, Li metal has been pursued for its high specific capacity and lowest standard potential. However, the hazardous Li dendrite growth is one of the most challenging issues for LMB, which brings about fragile SEI formation, low CE, large volume change and even safety issues. To tackle these problems, we design a 3D flexible MXene based lithium metal anode to accommodate the volume changes, accelerate the charge transport and lower the specific current density. Moreover, nonflammable ternary all-fluorinated carbonate electrolyte system is proposed to construct stable interface by introducing LiF-rich SEI and address the safety concerns. With these synergetic effects, 3D Li-MXene anode in ternary all-fluorinated electrolyte shows significantly improved reversibility with high average CE at 94.5 % after 200 cycles. Full Li metal cell with LFP cathode, composited 3D anode and nonflammable electrolyte delivers high-capacity retention of 95.7 % at 300 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles and excellent rate ability. These results pave a new direction for developing high safety and high-performance Li metal batteries and can also be extended to other rechargeable metal-anode-based batteries such as Na/K/Mg/Ca et al.

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Electrochemical and physical feature of electrolyte

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic diagram comparison of (a) serious Li dendrite growth on copper foil in the conventional electrolyte with common fragile SEI and (b) smooth Li deposition on advanced 3D MXene host in nonflammable all-fluorinated electrolyte we proposed with F-rich stable SEI. (c) Chemical structures of EC, DEC, FEC, FEMC, TFEC and LiFSI. (d) LSV curves of 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC and 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC. (e) Coulombic efficiency of Li||Cu cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC (red pattern), Li||MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC (green pattern) and Li||MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC (blue pattern) with fixed Li amount of 1 mAh cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2. (f-h) corresponding Li-metal plating curves on Cu/MXene electrode cycled in 1 M LiFSI in baseline electrolyte (EC: DEC = 1:1) or all-fluorinated electrolyte (FEC: FEMC: = 1:1:1), respectively.

An illustrative scheme of Li plating morphology on (a) copper foil and (b) MXene host. SEM images of Li deposition on (c) copper foil by depositing for (d) 2 h (e) 6 h (f) 10 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC. SEM images of Li deposition on (g) MXene host by depositing for (h) 2 h, (i) 6 h, (j) 10 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC.

Voltage-time curves for Li||Li-MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC and Li||Li-Cu cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC with 1.0 mAh cm−2Li at (a) 0.5 mA cm−2 and (b) 1.0 mA cm−2. (c) Local enlarged graphs after 1st, 20th, 30th and 50th in (b). (d) EIS spectra fitted by equivalent circuit model in Fig.S8 for symmetric cells working at 1.0 mA cm−2 after 1st and 20th. (e) Rate plating/stripping behavior of different symmetric cells at series of current density ranging from 0.5 to 5.0 mA cm−2 with Li amount of 1.0 mAh cm−2.
XPS characterization for Li metal in symmetric cells cycled after 20th at 1.0 mA cm−2 with (a,b) 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC and (c,d) 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC.

Scheme of Li dendrite growth on copper foil in baseline electrolyte and smooth Li deposition on MXene host with LiF-rich SEI-protected in all-fluorinated electrolyte. Li deposition morphology of (c) Li-Cu anode in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC and (d) Li-MXene anode in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC at 1 mA cm−2/1 mAh cm−2. Corresponding cross-sectional images of Li-Cu anode and Li-MXene anode after 20 cycles (end of discharging process) in (e) 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC and (f) 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC, respectively.

(a) Schematic illustration of the cell configuration and electrolyte composition of the all-fluorinated electrolyte. (b) long cycle performance of LFP||Li-Cu cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC and LFP||Li-MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC. (c,d) Charge-discharge capacity-voltage curves after specific cycles of corresponding cells. Nyquist plots fitted by equivalent circuit model in Fig.S8 of (e) LFP||Li-Cu cell with 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC (f) LFP||Li-MXene cell with 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC in the 20th, 50th and 100th cycling at 300 mAh g−1. Rate-ability test of (g) LFP||Li-Cu cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC and (h) LFP||Li-MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC at 50, 100, 200, 300,400,500 and 600 mAh g−1.

head.ce:title: Highly reversible and safe lithium metal batteries enabled by Non-flammable All-fluorinated carbonate electrolyte conjugated with 3D flexible MXene-based lithium anode

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Hefei National Laboratory for Physical Science at Microscale, Department of Chemistry, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Recognized as the most attractive and promising anode, Li metal has been pursued for its high specific capacity and lowest standard potential. However, the hazardous Li dendrite growth is one of the most challenging issues for LMB, which brings about fragile SEI formation, low CE, large volume change and even safety issues. To tackle these problems, we design a 3D flexible MXene based lithium metal anode to accommodate the volume changes, accelerate the charge transport and lower the specific current density. Moreover, nonflammable ternary all-fluorinated carbonate electrolyte system is proposed to construct stable interface by introducing LiF-rich SEI and address the safety concerns. With these synergetic effects, 3D Li-MXene anode in ternary all-fluorinated electrolyte shows significantly improved reversibility with high average CE at 94.5 % after 200 cycles. Full Li metal cell with LFP cathode, composited 3D anode and nonflammable electrolyte delivers high-capacity retention of 95.7 % at 300 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles and excellent rate ability. These results pave a new direction for developing high safety and high-performance Li metal batteries and can also be extended to other rechargeable metal-anode-based batteries such as Na/K/Mg/Ca et al.

ce:section.ce:para: The mainstream of using Li-ion battery is the road-block for further iteration of electric vehicles, portable devices, smart grid storage system, chiefly due to its physicochemical limit of theoretical capacity (372 mAh g−1) for currently used graphite-anode-based Li-ion battery [1-5]. Due to the following inherent merits of Li metal anode: (1) lowest electrochemical potential. (2) low density. (3) surprisingly high specific capacity, a wealthy of researches have been focused on Li metal battery (LMB) [6-9]. However, the commercial application of Li metal anode is a Gordian knot urgently waiting to be untied.

The mossy and dendritic Li growth is one of the most challenging issues for LMB, which brings about fragile SEI formation, low coulombic efficiency (CE), “dry up” of the electrolyte and capacity fading because of irreversible consumes of both metallic Li and liquid electrolyte [10-12]. Moreover, huge volume variation during Li plating/stripping process causes unsatisfactory electrical contact between dendrite Li and deposition layer, penetration through the common SEI with low interface energy at SEI/Li (in Fig. 1 a) [13-15]. Additionally, Li dendrite could pierce the separator mechanically and cause internal short circuit, resulting in a thermal runaway and other potential safety hazard [10,16]. Considerable efforts have been devoted to obtain dense and flat Li deposition. For example, three dimensional hosts with nanostructured morphology have been constructed to alternate commercially used copper foil in order to regulate the current distribution and Li nucleation sites [17-20]. Mechanically-strengthened separators are also fabricated to inhabit baneful Li dendrite growth [21-24]. Electrolyte modifications by use of electrolyte additives, fluorinated electrolyte and high-concentration Li salt aim to construct stable and robust SEI, which is essential to obtain effective Li metal batteries by suppressing Li dendrite growth [25-28].

Recently, fluorinated-rich SEI have been also adopted to block Li dendrite growth based on the following three advantages [29-36]: (1) a high interfacial energy at LiF/Li, which can inhibit dendritic and vertical Li growth and prevent Li penetration into SEI. (2) fast Li-ion kinetics due to high ionic conductivity of LiF. (3) excellent ability to insulate electrons. Accordingly, all-fluorinated electrolytes can not only ensure satisfactory contact between interface layer and bulk Li, but also avoid potential safety hazard thanks to the non-flammability. Besides, owing to its layered structure, good electron conductivity and flexibility, MXene has been proposed as an alternative substrate for commercial copper foil [37,38]. The excellent flexibility and rich surface area of MXene can buffer the volume change, lower current density, provide higher area capacity and facilitate Li ions transportation [39,40].

In this work, we design a 3D flexible MXene based lithium metal anode to accommodate the volume changes, lower current density and accelerate Li ions transportation. Moreover, nonflammable ternary all-fluorinated carbonate electrolyte system composed of 1 M lithium LiFSI dissolved in uniformly mixed fluorinated carbonate containing FEC, FEMC and TFEC (1:1:1 by volume) is proposed to construct stable interface by forming LiF-rich SEI to guide planar Li deposition and tackle safety issues (in Fig. 1b). It has been demonstrated that with the synergetic effect, Li-MXene anode in nonflammable ternary all-fluorinated delivers significantly enhanced reversibility with high average CE at 94.5 % after 200 cycles. These results also provide a new direction for developing high safety and high-performance Li metal batteries and can also be extended to other metal-anode-based batteries such as Na/K/Mg/Ca et al.

A new electrolyte system used in this work was prepared by adding 1 M LiFSI into mixed all-fluorinated carbonate solvents (FEC: FEMC: TFEC) by volume ratio of 1:1:1). The baseline electrolyte was composed of 1 M LiFSI dissolved in carbonate solvents (EC: DEC, 1:1 by volume). It is hereby declared that the baseline electrolyte in the following context was referred to 1 M LiFSI in EC: DEC (1:1 by volume). All the operating procedures were performed inside an argon-filled glovebox (H2O, O2 ≤ 0.01 ppm). The commercially used cathode was prepared by casting cathode slurry synthesized by stirring LiFePO4 (LFP), SP and 3% PVDF mixture (8:1:1 by weight ratio) for 10 h on Al foil and dried overnight at 80 ℃. The active material for each cell was about 1.07 ∼ 1.15 mg. Ti3C2 MXene was synthesized by etching 0.500 g Ti3AlC2 with in-situ formed etchant (0.800 g LiF in 10 mL 9 M HCl) at 36.5 ℃ for 24 h. After repeatedly centrifugation and hand-shaking, Ti3C2 MXene colloidal solution was collected, then filtered into disks and finally dried at 50 ℃ overnight. The metallic Li anode for full cell was prepared by depositing for 25 h at 0.2 mAh cm−2 on MXene host or copper foil. All electrodes were at a diameter of 10 mm.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical and physical feature of electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: Electrolyte flammability test for commercial carbonate electrolyte (EC/DEC) and all-fluorinated electrolyte (FEC/FEMC/TFEC) was performed by igniting the glass fiber strips infiltrated by 200 μL specific electrolyte and observing the consumption condition. We conducted ionic conductivity of related electrolyte by the conductivity meter (DDB-11A). LSV of Li|Stainless steel (SS) cells with different electrolyte was scanned from open-circuit voltage to 5.6 V at 1 mV s−1.

Powder X-ray diffractometer (MiniFlex 600, Japan) with 10 degree / minute step for 5 degree to 90 degree using Cu-Kα radiation was used to verify the syntheses of MXene-host. SEI composition of Li anode for symmetric cells after working 20 cycles was investigated by X-ray photo-electron spectrometer (Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi, USA). Morphology of Li deposition on MXene-host or copper foil with specific electrolyte was characterized by a scanning electron microscope (JSM-7610F).

2032 coin-type cells were utilized to evaluate electrochemical performance of electrodes. Approximately 80 μL electrolyte was dipped in each coin-type cell. To evaluate the Li plating/stripping efficiency, coulombic efficiency test was carried out with area capacity of 1, 3 and 5 mAh cm−2 on the MXene host or copper foil at 1, 3 and 5 mA cm−2. The galvanostatic discharge/charge test was performed by assembling symmetric cells working with Li mount of 1.0 mAh cm−2 at 0.5 mA cm−2 or 1.0 mA cm−2. The full cells were cycled at 300 mA g−1 with a cut-off voltage range of 3.0–4.2 V (vs. Li+/Li). The impedance of different type of cells after different cycles were measured by EIS recorded from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz.

Fig. 1c demonstrates the ball-and-stick models of LiFSI and solvents related to this work. Good thermal stability, solubility and conductivity endow LiFSI a promising Li salt for next generation lithium-ion battery [41]. EC/DEC are conventional solvents for lithium-ion battery. Recently, fluorinated carbonates have been confirmed to be endowed with superior anodic stability, electron withdrawing effect and LiF-rich SEI formation [36,42-44]. Moreover, it has been revealed that certain type of fluorinated carbonates are nonflammable [27,36]. In this work, the flammability tests of the new type of all-fluorinated electrolyte (1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC) was conducted in Fig. S1a-h. The baseline electrolyte (1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC) exhibits high flammability in Fig. S1a-d while the all-fluorinated electrolyte isn’t able to ignite in Fig. S1e-h, which proves all-fluorinated electrolyte possesses the nature of non-flammability. The outstanding fire retardancy is significant to dispel safety concerns. Conductivity is an important parameter which affects the rate performance of cells. In Fig. S2, the ionic conductivity of all-fluorinated electrolyte is 4.06 mS cm−1, lower than 8.19 mS cm−1 of baseline electrolyte. It’s has been reported that the conductivity has negative correlation to the degree of fluorination, meanwhile the linear electrolyte can reduce viscosity of pure cyclic carbonate [45,46]. It can be seen in Fig. 1d, the baseline electrolyte is decomposed around 4.6 V, while the all-fluorinated electrolyte can retain stable about 5.3 V. The LSV test demonstrates the outstanding electrochemical stability of all-fluorinated electrolyte and great potential in the application of high-voltage battery.

Li is deposited on MXene host and copper foil in baseline electrolyte to demonstrate the superior reversibility of Li metal on different substrate. As the Fig. 1e demonstrated, thanks to better lithiophilicity and 3D structure of MXene host, Li-MXene anode exhibits higher and more stable CE than Li-Cu anode at 1 mA cm−2/ 1 mAh cm−2. As shown in Fig. 1g and h, lower Li deposition overpotential and higher charge capacity of Li-MXene anode also confirm that MXene host can improve Li deposition condition [47,48].

3D flexible MXene host is also adopted in all-fluorinated electrolyte. As exhibited in Fig. 1e, Li-MXene anode in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC displays obviously prolonged lifespan and high average CE at 94.5 % after 200 cycles. Even when the current density raises up to 3 and 5 mA cm−2, the Li-MXene anode in all-fluorinated electrolyte can also keep excellent CE above 95 % after 60 cycles in Fig. S3a and b. Moreover, the Li plating/stripping potentials of Li-MXene anode in all-fluorinated electrolyte in Fig. 1f is stable and the charge capacity is much higher than the MXene electrode working in baseline electrolyte, though its conductivity is lower than that of baseline carbonate (in Fig. S2). It can be speculated that the all-fluorinated electrolyte is incline to form Li-rich SEI film with high interfacial energy, which may promote lateral and flat Li deposition to decrease unwanted Li metal and electrolyte consumption [44,49]. As a result, the Li-MXene anode in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC demonstrates remarkable cyclic performance and reversibility during Li plating/stripping process. Thus, we adopt three-dimensional flexible MXene serving as a host in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC for following experiment to explore the effectiveness and stability of dual promotion to alternate conventional current collector and carbonate electrolyte. And the successful synthesis of MXene paper using for this work can be confirmed by the shift of peak from 9.77° of Ti3AlC2 to 6.97° of Ti3C2Tx and the disappearance of peak located at 39.0° of Ti3AlC2 (in Fig. S4) [40].

SEM was performed to explore the Li deposition behavior on MXene host in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC. As the schematic graph in Fig. 2 a and b illustrated, Li deposited on copper foil in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC presents obvious dendrite-like morphology as the Li amount increasing, while the morphologies of Li are flat on MXene host in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC. SEM images of Li deposition conducted at 0.5 mA cm−2 lasting for different hours are displayed in Fig. 2c-j. Li deposition on copper foil (Fig. 2c-f) in baseline electrolyte exhibits large areas of roughness surface with dendrite-like and seriously corroded Li distributed in random orientations. On the contrary, in all-fluorinated electrolyte, Li is deposited uniformly and flat on MXene host without Li dendrite growth in Fig. 2g-j. In Fig. S5a-c, it is obvious that Li deposited on MXene paper in baseline electrolyte displays more flat morphology and less Li dendrite than it on copper foil overall due to enhanced lithiophilicity and three-dimensional micro-structure of MXene host. However, the lithiophilic elements on MXene paper are unevenly distributed and fragile SEI always generates in common carbonate electrolyte, thus ununiform Li deposition and Li dendrite growth can also be observed on MXene paper. It can be deduced from three dimensions to explain the significant enhance of Li deposition morphology on MXene host in all-fluorinated electrolyte [19,29,37,44,48]: (1) As displayed in Fig. S6, lithiophilic elements such as C, O and F on MXene host are positive to lower the nucleation barrier and guide even Li deposition. (2) rich surface and 3D structure of MXene host as shown in Fig. S7 can lower specific current density and facilitate Li ions transport. (3) high LiF/Li interface energy can suppress the vertical Li dendrite growth by encouraging lateral Li+ migration and deposition. (4) formation of highly fluorinated and more stable SEI also enable uniform and smooth Li deposition.

To investigate long cycle performance during Li metal plating/stripping process on MXene host in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC all-fluorinated electrolyte. At 0.5 mA cm−2/1.0 mAh cm−2, Li||Li-MXene cell in Fig. 3 a displays small and stable voltage hysteresis and long lifespan at 650 h, about three times longer than Li||Li-Cu cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC, which reflects small polarization and effective inhibition of Li dendrite growth of symmetric cell. The impedance measurements were also carried out to evaluate the interface impedance in 1st, 20th and 50th cycling at 0.5 mA cm−2 of symmetrical cells. In Fig. S9, the interface resistance of Li||Li-MXene cell in all-fluorinated electrolyte is 31 Ω in first cycling, much lower than 99 Ω of Li||Li-Cu cell in baseline electrolyte, indicating thicker SEI film formation at initial stage of Li||Li-MXene cell. And the values of interface resistance of symmetric cell in all-fluorinated electrolyte maintain around 20 Ω, while the interface resistance of symmetric cell in baseline electrolyte exhibits much larger change from 67 Ω to 42 Ω. When we elevate the current density to 1.0 mA cm−2 with same area capacity, the polarization of symmetric cells increases and the lifespan is shorter in Fig. 3b, which can be ascribed to stimulation of dendritic Li growth at higher current density. However, the Li||Li-MXene cell still demonstrates more stable cyclic performance in Fig. 3b and c than Li||Li-Cu cell. Nyquist plots of symmetric cells at 1.0 mA cm−2 in Fig. 3d confirms thicker and more stable SEI formation in Li||Li-MXene cell. The significantly enhanced cyclic performance of Li||Li-MXene cells in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC is mainly benefited from 3D flexible MXene host and LiF/Li interface which can effectively prevent hazardous Li dendrite growth and boost the Li+ transport [36]. Voltage-time curves at different current density for Li plating/stripping with fixed Li amount at 1.0 mA cm−2 is shown in Fig. 3e. The Li||Li-Cu cell in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC possesses higher polarization and voltage plateau than the Li||Li-MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC, which also proves 3D structure host and high LiF/Li interface energy can promote the Li+ transport [50].

XPS was conducted to analyze the chemical compositions of the interface formed on Li-MXene anode. The C 1 s spectrum in Fig. 4 a and c shows the organic-related ingredients are mainly composed of C − C/C − H (∼284.8 eV), and C − O (∼286.6 eV), C = O (288.4 eV) and ROCO2Li (∼289.8 eV) [43,44,51]. By contrast, the strength and content of organic-related peaks in Fig. 4a are stronger than those in Fig. 4c, indicating the SEI film formed in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC is more stable by inhibiting the collapse/regeneration to avoid electrolyte consumption and the formation of “dead Li” [26]. Typically, the F 1 s spectra in Fig. 4b and d indicates two peaks noted as inorganic LiF (∼685.0 eV) originated form decomposition of LiFSI and or fluorinated solvents (when applicable), and organic ingredient (C-F, ∼688.0 eV) [52]. In 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC electrolyte system, the F element only originated form the decomposition of LiFSI. As a result, the content of LiF is much lower than it in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC electrolyte system. Known as a particularly desirable component of SEI for Li anodes, LiF possesses high interface energy, high ionic conductivity and excellent electrochemical stability [44]. Therefore, highly fluorinated SEI result in high CE and stable cyclic performance of Li plating/stripping process.

To further realize the Li deposition morphologies of symmetric cells in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC electrolyte system, SEM images of Li anodes are exhibited in Fig. 5 c-f. The poor lithiophilicity of copper foil and non-uniform SEI formed in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC electrolyte system lead to inhomogeneous Li deposition. Thus, Li ions around humps will attract more Li flux, aggravating the vertical Li growth dendrites (illustrated in Fig. 5a). From the SEM images of Li anode after 20 cycles, needle-like, porous and cracking Li deposition on copper foil can be seen in Fig. 5c and e. By contrast, in the 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC electrolyte system, Fig. 5d and f display even and planar Li deposition on MXene host due to the 3D flexible substrate and uniform F-rich SEI with high interface energy against Li metal, which is favorable to guide planar, dense and uniform Li deposition (illustrated in Fig. 5b) [34]. Notably, dense and smooth Li deposition in Fig. 5f can lower Li and electrolyte consumption and reduce the possibility to penetrate separators and, which confirms EIS tests in Fig. 3d and the veracity of the electrochemical performance in Fig. 3b. Moreover, MXene host has tighter contact with Li metal than copper foil (in Fig. 5e and f) owing to its flexible and 3D structure (in Fig. S7) can better alleviate huge volume variation [13].

As Fig. 6 a illustrated, commercial LFP cathode is used to couple with Li-MXene anode in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC non-flammable electrolyte system, and we believed that F-rich SEI can stable Li anode and also exhibit good electrochemical performance for full batteries. In Fig. 6b, LFP||Li-Cu and LFP||Li-MXene full cells were evaluated in 1 M LiFSI/EC-DEC and 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC electrolytes at a high rate of 300 mAh g−1. Obviously, the discharge capacity of LFP||Li-MXene cell is stable and exhibits small degradation, which can remain 119.2 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles, nearly 95.7 % capacity retention of the original discharge capacity. By contrast, LFP||Li-Cu cell delivers a sharp reduction of discharge capacity to 62.2 mAh g−1 after 90 cycles. As displayed in Fig. 6c and d, the voltage-capacity curves of the LFP||Li-MXene cell exhibits flatter and smaller voltage hysteresis between the charge/discharge process than the LFP||Li-Cu cell, which can be attributed to the repeatedly severe SEI passivation/pulverization is inhabited in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC electrolyte system and the stable LiF-rich SEI and 3D structure host can accelerate Li+ transportation to promote electrode kinetics with lower impedance [35]. The EIS tests in Fig. 6e and f also prove the high electrode kinetics of LFP||Li-MXene cell with LiF-rich SEI. As working cycles increasing, the interface impedance of LFP||Li-MXene shows slight rise from 83.95 Ω to 119.61 Ω, much lower than the sharp growth of LFP||Li-Cu cell from 155.82 Ω to 473.70 Ω (in Fig. S10). By running at series of current density, the rate ability of LFP||Li-MXene cell in 1 M LiFSI/FEC-FEMC-TFEC is evaluated. In Fig. 6g, h and S11, even at 600 mA g−1, the LFP||Li-MXene cell in all-fluorinated electrolyte can still retain high discharge capacity around 108 mA g−1, ∼ 48 mA g−1 more than LFP||Li-Cu cell in baseline electrolyte, indicating 3D MXene host and LiF-rich SEI on Li surface can boost Li ions transport kinetics [52].

To conclude, a stable 3D Li anode with stable F-rich SEI interface is designed by introducing a new nonflammable ternary all-fluorinated carbonated electrolyte system. The flexible 3D MXene host can buffer volume change, lower specific current density and regulate Li+ flux. The all-fluorinated electrolyte can effectively address safety issues thanks to its nonflammable nature, but also generate stable and high interfacial energy LiF-rich SEI. Therefore, Li-MXene anode in nonflammable ternary all-fluorinated exhibits significantly enhanced reversibility with high average CE at 94.5 % after 200 cycles at 1.0 mA cm−2 compared with Li-Cu anode and Li-MXene anode in baseline electrolyte and shows prolonged lifespan around 650 h at 0.5 mA cm−2/ 1.0 mAh cm−2 in symmetric cells. Full Li metal cell with LFP cathode, composited 3D anode and nonflammable electrolyte achieved superior rate ability and long cycle performance with capacity retention at 95.7 % at 300 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. Moreover, these results provide a new direction for developing high safety and high-performance Li metal batteries and can also be extended to other metal-anode-based batteries such as Na/K/Mg/Ca et al.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Interfacial Study on Solid Electrolyte Interphase at Li Metal Anode: Implication for Li Dendrite Growth
